name: Australian TV in the 1980s
description: Australian television in the 80s really began to find its footing with mainstream hits becoming landmarks of the industry.

key_work.title: 1980s Australian TV miniature
key_work.credit_line: Designed by Graham McGuffie, Emily Boutard and Megafun
key_work.brief_description: This gorgeous miniature model celebrates the evolving design of rooms where Australians watch TV, as well as the most memorable shows from the 1980s.

constellations_primary.name: Australian TV in the 1980s
constellations_primary.description: Australian television in the 80s really began to find its footing with mainstream hits becoming landmarks of the industry.

start.title: Acropolis Now
start.credit_line:
Courtesy Crawford DVD

Acropolis Now is held in the collection of the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
start.brief_description: In the 1980s, roles for Greek actors were limited, so they created their own - first the stage show Wogs out of Work (1987), and then the sitcom Acropolis Now, one of the first TV shows to bring much-needed diversity to Australian screens.

constellations_primary.name: Culture, food and family
constellations_primary.description: Food as a link to culture and family.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1980s
constellations_other.description: Australian television in the 80s really began to find its footing with mainstream hits becoming landmarks of the industry.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

end.title: Fast Forward
end.brief_description: Fast Forward was Australiaâ€™s highest rating, longest-running and most critically awarded commercial television sketch comedy show, broadcast for 90 one hour episodes from 12 April 1989 to 26 November 1992.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1980s
constellations_other.description: Australian television in the 80s really began to find its footing with mainstream hits becoming landmarks of the industry.

links.description: Following the lives of the owners and workers at a Greek cafe in Melbourne, Acropolis Now was one of the first examples of Australian immigrant stories in mainstream pop culture. It debuted the same year as Fast Forward, which also had a four-year run.

end.title: Sale of the Century
end.brief_description: $ale of the Century was a game show that aired from 1980 to 2001, hosted by Tony Barber, who’d essentially hosted the same format, temptation, in the 70s.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1980s
constellations_other.description: Australian television in the 80s really began to find its footing with mainstream hits becoming landmarks of the industry.

links.description: In the 1980s Australian TV emulated its international counterparts, which had programs across all different genres and formats. The game show was one of the most popular models in the US and UK particularly, with Sale Of The Century becoming the homegrown answer.

start.title: Sale of the Century
start.brief_description: $ale of the Century was a game show that aired from 1980 to 2001, hosted by Tony Barber, who’d essentially hosted the same format, temptation, in the 70s.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1980s
constellations_other.description: Australian television in the 80s really began to find its footing with mainstream hits becoming landmarks of the industry.

end.title: Perfect Match
end.brief_description: Perfect Match is an Australian dating game show based on the format of The Dating Game. Perfect Match was produced by the Reg Grundy Organisation.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1980s
constellations_other.description: Australian television in the 80s really began to find its footing with mainstream hits becoming landmarks of the industry.

links.description: Sale Of The Century was a staple in Australian households, with the show even living on through merch, like a popular boardgame. It paved the way for other local gameshows like Perfect Match, which was a riff on the American version The Dating Game.

start.title: Perfect Match
start.brief_description: Perfect Match is an Australian dating game show based on the format of The Dating Game. Perfect Match was produced by the Reg Grundy Organisation.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1980s
constellations_other.description: Australian television in the 80s really began to find its footing with mainstream hits becoming landmarks of the industry.

end.title: Board games
end.brief_description: These were the television shows that became a part of our family, like relatives that came by to visit a few nights a week. There were hosts that audiences loved, guests they often didn’t and formats so recognisable they felt like a warm blanket. Board game versions of our most popular quiz shows were another way these programmes embedded themselves in our lives. The games allowed us to imagine finding a romantic partner on Perfect Match or walking away with cash prizes on The Price Is Right. Even as game-show formats changed on the small screen, the version inside the box lived on.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1980s
constellations_other.description: Australian television in the 80s really began to find its footing with mainstream hits becoming landmarks of the industry.

links.description: In the 1980s, many board games were based on TV game shows, whose quiz format easily translated into at-home entertainment. You can see one from The Price is Right in our display in the Fed Sq foyer.

start.title: Perfect Match
start.brief_description: Perfect Match is an Australian dating game show based on the format of The Dating Game. Perfect Match was produced by the Reg Grundy Organisation.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1980s
constellations_other.description: Australian television in the 80s really began to find its footing with mainstream hits becoming landmarks of the industry.

end.title: Neighbours
end.creator_credit: Fremantle Australia and Reg Grundy Productions Pty. Ltd.
end.brief_description: Everybody needs good neighbours and for over 35 years the residents of Ramsay Street have shared their lives, loves and laugher with us. Featuring tragic love stories, long-lost family members and mysterious resurrections, Neighbours has been part of the family for a generation.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1980s
constellations_other.description: Australian television in the 80s really began to find its footing with mainstream hits becoming landmarks of the industry.

links.description: Perfect Match introduced the beloved robot Dexter, who mathematically matched contestants with a compatibility score. Love was at the forefront of viewers mind in the 80s, with it being one of the central themes of enduring Aussie soap Neighbours.

start.title: Neighbours
start.creator_credit: Fremantle Australia and Reg Grundy Productions Pty. Ltd.
start.brief_description: Everybody needs good neighbours and for over 35 years the residents of Ramsay Street have shared their lives, loves and laugher with us. Featuring tragic love stories, long-lost family members and mysterious resurrections, Neighbours has been part of the family for a generation.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1980s
constellations_other.description: Australian television in the 80s really began to find its footing with mainstream hits becoming landmarks of the industry.

end.title: Home and Away
end.brief_description: Home and Away is with us each day… well at least each weekday. Set in Summer Bay, this frothy soap has been a stalwart of Australian screens and one of its longest-running shows, as well as a launchpad for its stars.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1980s
constellations_other.description: Australian television in the 80s really began to find its footing with mainstream hits becoming landmarks of the industry.

links.description: The residents of Ramsay St in Neighbours lived on despite a shaky start. First cancelled by Seven, it migrated to Channel Ten with a more youthful approach. A massive international success Home And Away followed in its footsteps just a few years later.

start.title: Home and Away
start.brief_description: Home and Away is with us each day… well at least each weekday. Set in Summer Bay, this frothy soap has been a stalwart of Australian screens and one of its longest-running shows, as well as a launchpad for its stars.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

links.description: Trading the suburbia for the beach, Home And Away became a launchpad for some of Australia’s biggest stars like Chris Hemsworth and Heath Ledger. So too was Acropolis Now, which kickstarted the careers of Nick Giannopoulos, Mary Coustas and even Russell Crowe.
